Award.AwardTitle: Disruption to cortical dopamine systems following adolescent social stress
Award.AbstractNarration:
While mammalian adolescence is an incredibly formative time, it is also a period of increased susceptibility to the negative effects of stress exposure. In particular, cognitive deficits seen in adulthood are thought to result from stress-induced disruption of the prefrontal cortex dopamine system, which undergoes dynamic alterations during adolescence. For many adolescent mammals, a common form of stress is social aggression, but it is not known precisely how this may affect the cortical dopamine system to result in later cognitive dysfunction. This research will use a rat model to test the hypothesis that the adolescent cortical dopamine system is particularly vulnerable to social stress, by examining effects of social aggression experienced in adolescence on various markers known to regulate dopamine activity. Changes in these markers will then be related to negative alterations in cognitive function, with complimentary experiments examining whether cognitive deficits can be reversed pharmacologically. Findings will provide novel information about how an essential brain system that changes dramatically during adolescence can be negatively affected by socio-environmental factors to result in long term maladaptive behavioral expression, thus furnishing further insight into the development of mechanisms regulating prefrontal cortex dopamine activity across adolescence into adulthood.

The project will have broad educational impact. South Dakotan students from pre-college to graduate level will have the opportunity to participate in these studies, providing them with meaningful and valuable research experiences as necessary for a successful career in science. The investigators will also volunteer to present and discuss this work at regional high schools, undergraduate and tribal colleges and the greater community. This will disseminate scientific knowledge to a wider audience, highlighting the negative impacts of social stress during adolescence to relevant groups, and exposing these groups to the potentials of scientific research and teaching as a vocation that directly contributes to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mammalian adolescence is an incredibly formative time, enabling an individual to make the transition from being a juvenile dependent on parental care to being a functional independent adult.  This requires the adolescent to seek out new situations, many of which involve a high element of risk.  However, this increased risk taking makes adolescence a period of increased susceptibility to the negative effects of stress exposure.  In particular, cognitive deficits seen in adulthood are thought to result from stress-induced disruption of the prefrontal cortex dopamine system, which undergoes dynamic alterations during adolescence.  For many adolescent mammals, a common form of stress is social aggression, but it is not known precisely this may affect the cortical dopamine system to result in later cognitive dysfunction.  This is extremely important to understand, because the resulting cognitive deficits may permanently impair an individual’s ability to cope with adult life.  This is true for a range of mammalian species, including primates such as humans.

The research supported by this NSF award used a rat model to test the hypothesis that the adolescent cortical dopamine system is particularly vulnerable to social stress, by examining effects of social aggression experienced in adolescence on various markers known to regulate dopamine activity.  These studies were carried out by graduate and undergraduate students under the guidance of Dr. Michael Watt at the University of South Dakota.  Over the four year funding period, Watt and his team were able to show that rats exposed to adolescent social stress had lasting deficits in availability of the neurotransmitter dopamine in the prefrontal cortex when they reached adulthood.  Specifically, mechanisms controlling dopamine clearance and release became sensitized, so that dopamine in cortical synapses is removed too quickly before it has the chance to activate its neural targets.  In addition, any dopamine that remains rapidly turns on auto-inhibitory mechanisms, which prevent further dopamine release and compound the lack of availability. 

With insufficient dopamine activity, the prefrontal cortex loses its efficiency to carry out critical cognitive tasks.  These include working memory, which is the brain’s ability to maintain information relevant to a task over short delay periods (an example for humans would be remembering a new phone number while trying to find pen and paper to write it down).  Without good working memory, it becomes difficult to stay on track mentally and ignore distractions, which can impair decision making and thus promote behavior that is not suitable for a given situation.  In line with this, Watt and his team found that rats that had experienced social stress in adolescence displayed working memory deficits as adults.  Artificially increasing dopamine in the prefrontal cortex reversed these deficits, establishing for the first time a direct mechanistic link between disruption to cortical DA activity caused by adolescent social stress and later cognitive impairments.

The researchers also established when changes to regulation of cortical dopamine availability emerged in relation to the adolescent stress experience, and compared this to age-matched rats that never experienced this stressor.  This showed that the development of these mechanisms during adolescence is severely disrupted, and even suggest that social stress exposure encourages retention of an adolescent-like cortical dopamine system rather than allowing maturation to the form needed for adult life.  Combined, findings have provided novel information about how an essential brain system that changes dramatically during adolescence can be negatively affected by social stress to result in long term maladaptive behavioral expression.  This is essential for increasing our knowledge regarding brain-behavior relationships over a critical developmental period, and how this may be influenced by socio-environmental factors.

This project provided valuable research experiences for university students ranging from undergraduate to doctoral level.  Importantly, students involved in this project were from predominantly rural areas (South Dakota and surrounding regions), which traditionally offer limited access to such research opportunities.  Findings from this project have also been used as illustrative examples of the scientific research process in outreach activities to high school students from the local region, including those from tribal reservations.  This provides these students with access to the possibilities inherent in scientific research, which promotes entry into careers based in the sciences.  Theoretical themes and results from this project will continue to be presented both to the scientific community and to the general public.  In doing so, the negative impacts of social stress during adolescence become more widely appreciated, while also exposing current and future generations to the potentials of scientific research as a career that directly contributes to society.
